audio_caption: The audio clip begins with male tenor vocals, singing with clear, passionate tones to an emotional ballad, led by a piano melody and subtle strings. The music abruptly stops as a female speaker enthusiastically states that the song "tickles down the spine," introducing the next guest, who was selected by Brian May and Roger Taylor to voice Freddy Mercury. Her audition received 14 million YouTube views, resulting in a performance on Ellen, extensive touring, and a performance for Celine Dion. The man was hand-picked as the voice of Freddy in the movie Bohemian Rhapsody. The female speaker introduces Mark Martel, welcoming him to the show.

The clip starts with an expression of gratitude from a male speaker, saying "Thanks for having me, I'm so excited to be here". A female speaker responds warmly, "It is so nice to have you here". She refers to "that little video then", mentioning it gave her chills and praising the music within it as beautiful. The male speaker expresses that this was "the desired reaction". The female speaker acknowledges the reaction, and a short musical interlude begins.

The audio clip begins with a female interviewer speaking in an inquisitive tone. She acknowledges the speaker as a singer in his own right before fame, noting his resemblance to Freddie Mercury. She asks about his life before the comparison. A male speaker responds in a conversational tone, describing being in a band with the usual experiences of musicians: traveling in a van and sometimes sleeping in it overnight. He recalls "slogging it out" for almost fifteen years until the "Queen thing started."

The audio clip begins with a conversational tone, where one speaker asks another whether their voice is natural or a product of nurture, such as if they were told they sound like "Freddie" or if there was characterization. The speaker replies that it's a "little bit of both", explaining that they learned to sing by imitating, having a natural ear for mimicry, then goes on to reference Quebec and Celine. The speaker jokes about the name drop, and shares that growing up, they had "the propensity to try to imitate" what they heard and that George Michael was a big influence. The speaker notes that as their voice matured, they began to receive comparisons to Freddie Mercury even before they were familiar with more than their three biggest hits. Someone responds that this is "quite an extraordinary" thing.

The clip begins with a female speaker inquiring whether, at the beginning of his career, the other speaker tried to sound less like Freddy Mercury. A male speaker responds that he tried not to sound like him, adding that this became a joke. He says he would tell his bandmates he would try to sound like someone else, but ended up getting more Freddy Mercury comparisons that night. He concludes that he has accepted he will never be able to escape it and has embraced it.

The audio features a male speaker commenting on being compared to someone great in their field, then describes auditioning for a Queen tribute and performing on Ellen. The speaker then notes their initial audition video was uploaded in September 2011, with Ellen's people contacting them by early October. They conclude with a humorous comment about experiencing a viral video.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing how his wife said she lost her husband for a few weeks because he was constantly on YouTube, then expresses relief that the feedback he received was mostly positive. A second female speaker then mentions how people now recognize his voice and compare it to someone elseâ€™s. The first male speaker admits to initial reluctance to audition, citing his own band and their relative success with radio play, fearing that joining Queen would disrupt it. He recalls feeling conflicted, worried about impacting his bandmates' lives, but his wife encouraged him, saying he was "born for this." The overall speaking tone is conversational and reflective, creating an atmosphere of relaxed storytelling.

The clip begins with a male speaker saying, "you know, thought it was." Another male speaker responds with "Collect and turn." He then asks "How has life changed? It must be phenomenal." The first speaker responds that it's still music and that it's playing music people recognize. He says it's a rush to play songs that everyone knows just as well as you do. He contrasts that with when you're in your own band doing your own music. He mentions that you have your core fans, but there's also a huge part of the audience that you're trying to sell your music to because they've never heard it before.

Two speakers, male and female, engage in a conversation about the enduring appeal of the band Queen, noting their music's presence in the "zeitgeist for 40 years." The male speaker mentions ending performances with "We Are the Champions" and "We Will Rock You," eliciting a "standing ovation." The female speaker agrees, emphasizing that Queen has "so many feel-good songs."

The audio features a conversation between two people, presumably an interviewer and interviewee. The interviewer prompts the interviewee to share a story about a performance on Ellen. In response, the interviewee describes the experience as cool and Ellen as sweet, noting it felt like a TV studio. The interviewee also recalls the experience as being somewhat of a blur.

The clip begins with a male speaker reflecting on touring with Roger Taylor from the original Queen band. He describes Taylor's involvement, stating he's heavily involved with the Queen Extravaganza, clarifying that Taylor was never in the band but is at the helm. The speaker conveys a friendly, appreciative tone. His comments are followed by a female speaker's brief comment about touring with Roger Taylor.

The audio clip begins with a female interviewer speaking in an excited tone, setting up a question about a film called "Bohemian Rhapsody" and an actor playing Freddie Mercury. She then asks the interviewee about his involvement in the film's music. A male speaker responds in a conversational tone, mentioning being asked to be part of the film. He confirms that the "voice of Freddie will be a mixture" of Freddie Mercury, the actor, and himself. The female interviewer then expresses surprise, and the male speaker agrees it's a secret. Another male voice pipes in, playfully asking if they can get more information. This male voice continues speaking, recalling the speaker's knack for impersonating George Michael. He asks if the interviewee can provide more "secrets." The interviewee shares that he learned how to sing falsetto from listening to "New Kids on the Block", mentioning Jordan Knight as one of his heroes. He lists Jeff Buckley and Richard Marx as additional influences. The second male voice excitedly asks for "a little Right Here Waiting", revealing he is a fan. The speaker acknowledges the listener's fandom, stating that the musician is a great songwriter.

The clip begins with two speakers, one female and one male, in a friendly, conversational tone. The female speaker introduces a show called "The Ultimate Queen Celebration" and asks about it. The male speaker responds, describing the show as a greatest hits performance with high energy. He highlights the flexibility in the set list, mentioning the inclusion of songs that Queen didn't record. This is followed by the female speaker, reacting with excitement. Lastly, the male speaker continues to discuss the set list. A cymbal crash is briefly heard after the female speaker reacts to the show.

The audio begins with a male speaker describing Queen as one of the only bands that could fill two hours of music with "all greatest hits." He mentions "Bohemian Rhapsody," "Under Pressure," "Fat Bottom Girls," "Tie Your Mother Down," and "I Want To Break Free," implying that, if it's a great song, it's in the show. This is followed by an affirmative response from a second speaker, then the first speaker adds, "awesome, so many good songs."

The audio starts with a female speaker asking if the other person likes the song "Don't Stop Me Now." A male speaker responds in the affirmative, calling it his favorite. The female expresses excitement and mentions it's her all-time favorite for motivation. The male speaker lists other favorite songs, including "Under Pressure" and "Love of My Life", but agrees that "Don't Stop Me Now" is a top favorite. The female speaker expresses gratitude for their chat and anticipation for a later performance.

The audio clip begins with a woman speaking in an enthusiastic and informative tone about a performance by "Matar" celebrating the Queen, taking place in Auckland and Christchurch. She mentions "Ticketmaster" and "Ticketek" for details. A male speaker then responds, also in an enthusiastic tone, highlighting the performance's name, "You Take My Breath Away", noting that rehearsals have been great. Upbeat pop music, with an inspirational and triumphant mood, plays in the background as the woman concludes, mentioning that more will come after a chat with "Holly".
